Authors:
Didier Salmon, Carsten Krumbholz, Markus Kador, Sabine
Bachmaier, Jasmin Anna Gossmann, Pierrick Uzureau, Etienne Pays, Michael
Boshart
Title:
The ESAG4 sub-family of adenylyl cyclases is required for
cytokinesis of Trypanosoma brucei bloodstream forms
Keywords: adenylyl cyclase, ESAG4, GRESAG4, cytokinesis, RNAi
Abstract:
For antigenic variation of the parasite Trypanosoma brucei
monoallelic variant surface glycoprotein (VSG) expression is selected
from a collection of multiple telomeric VSG expression sites (ESs). Each
of these ESs harbours a long polycistronic transcription unit containing
several expression site-associated genes (ESAGs). ESAG4 copies encode
bloodstream stage-specific adenylyl cyclases and belong to a larger
family of around 80 members, the majority of which, termed genes related
to ESAG4 (GRESAG4s), are not encoded in ESs and are expressed
constitutively in the life cycle. Here we report that ablation of ESAG4
from the active ES did not affect parasite growth, neither in culture
nor upon rodent infection, consistent with no significant change in
total cyclase activity. In contrast, inducible RNAi-mediated knockdown
of the ESAG4 sub-family, that includes two ESAG4-like GRESAG4s,
decreased total adenylyl cyclase (AC) activity and induced a lethal
phenotype linked to impaired cytokinesis. Compensatory upregulation of
apparently functionally redundant ESAG4-like GRESAG4s is observed in the
âˆ†esag4 line and suggests that the level of total AC expression is
critical for cell division in the bloodstream stage, rather than
ES-linked expression or an isoform-specific signaling event.
Accordingly, the ESAG4 sub-family does not appear to be involved in
cellular differentiation.
